headline: 'I didn't like Man Utd managerial target - he blocked me and isn't a great coach'
body: Ruud van Nistelrooy is reportedly one man on Manchester United's shortlist of potential managers to take over until the end of the season - a matter of months after the Dutchman was torn apart by one of his former players.

Van Nistelrooy, who had a four-game spell as United's caretaker boss last season, has been out of work since leaving Leicester City back in June. But according to the Daily Mail, the 49-year-old is being considered by United as someone that could take charge until the end of the campaign, after Ruben Amorim was sacked.
Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, who previously spent almost three years as United's manager between 2018 and 2021, is among the frontrunners on the shortlist alongside Van Nistelrooy.

Should Van Nistelrooy be given the United job, it would be his first managerial role since a disastrous seven-month stint at Leicester last season. Van Nistelrooy took over from Steve Cooper at the King Power Stadium in November 2024, but won just five of his 27 Premier League matches in charge. The Foxes ended up finishing 18th, 10 points adrift of safety and became the first top-flight club to go nine games without scoring at home.

Van Nistelrooy's record at Leicester was dismal, it's safe to say, and it hasn't convinced many of his managerial capabilities. Someone who wasn't convinced was Odsonne Edouard, who spent last season on loan at the Foxes from Crystal Palace. Edouard, 27, made six appearances under Cooper before being completely cast aside by Van Nistelrooy. The Frenchman made the bench just once under the ex-PSV Eindhoven boss.
After finding his form with Lens this season, scoring seven times in 14 Ligue 1 matches, Edouard delivered a brutal verdict on Van Nistelrooy back in October and said he is not a 'great coach'.
"Being a great striker doesn't necessarily mean being a great coach," Edouard told L'Equipe. "After training, I would do an even harder session with my fitness coach. I didn't give up.
"Leicester, it had a professional impact on me. I don't really have any reasons. At the beginning, I played a little [under Steve Cooper], then things didn't work out with Van Nistelrooy.
"I didn't get along well with Van Nistelrooy. I found myself blocked for seven months without playing."

Before his troubled time at Leicester, Van Nistelrooy enjoyed a successful four-game reign as United's caretaker head coach following Erik ten Hag's dismissal in October 2024. He won three and drew the other of his four matches, with two of those victories coming against Cooper's Leicester in the Carabao Cup and Premier League. Van Nistelrooy's other win came against PAOK in the Europa League, while the draw came at home to Chelsea.
Amorim was then appointed as United's new head coach and he decided not to keep Van Nistelrooy, who was offered the Leicester job two weeks later, as part of his backroom staff.

headline: How Man Utd’s former stars have performed as interim bosses as club chiefs repeat the trick
body: Manchester United are looking to the past for a future managerial appointment. The Red Devils are on the hunt for a new face in the dugout following the sacking of Ruben Amorim and it could be a familiar one.

The Portuguese coach was dismissed earlier this week following a disappointing 14 months in charge. While club chiefs will be on the lookout for a permanent replacement, an interim appointment appears to be the most likely course of action.

And a number of former United stars have emerged as contenders to claim the role. According to numerous reports, former boss Ole Gunnar Solskjaer is a frontrunner to claim the role after early talks and has been spotted in Cheshire.

Darren Fletcher, who has been handed the caretaker position, is another option, while ex-teammate Michael Carrick could also be parachuted in. Ruud van Nistelrooy is another name to have been mentioned, having fulfilled the same role to success last term.

But is that always the way when United opt for an interim manager? Take a look at some of the Red Devils’ most recent returning faces and how they got on after claiming a spot in the Old Trafford hotseat:

Replacing Sir Alex Ferguson was always going to be a lofty task for United. And David Moyes was only given a short period in which to do that after being personally headhunted by the legendary Scottish manager.

He was sacked midway through his first season and was replaced by club legend Ryan Giggs. The Welshman turned to a host of youth players towards the end of the season and rounded off his stint in charge with a number of positive results.
He beat Norwich 4-0 in his opening game, before slipping to a 1-0 defeat to Sunderland. United saw off Hull City 3-1, before Giggs’ temporary spell concluded with a 1-1 draw against Southampton.
Giggs was confirmed as assistant boss to the incoming Louis van Gaal, while he then departed the club with the arrival of Jose Mourinho.

On the topic of the Portuguese, he was actually replaced by another interim option. It was certainly a surprise to see Solskjaer handed the reins at Old Trafford following a dismal spell with Cardiff City.

But it was an inspired decision from United, with Solskjaer winning 14 of his 19 matches as interim manager - a run of form that saw him handed the job on a full-term basis. Highlights from his caretaker spell included a 5-1 win against Cardiff on his debut, as well as a memorable Champions League win against Paris Saint-Germain.

The Norwegian also led United to the 2021 Europa League final but was unable to claim the trophy against Ajax. Solskjaer was eventually sacked just under three years after being appointed and was replaced by another former United star.
Following the success that they had enjoyed with Solskjaer, United attempted to repeat the trick with a move for former midfielder Michael Carrick, who had held roles under Mourinho and Solskjaer.

Carrick was retained following the exit of the latter and was appointed on a caretaker basis. He enjoyed a dream start by beating Villarreal in the Champions League, while he also secured a respectable draw with Chelsea in his first league game.

Carrick rounded off his caretaker spell by beating Arsenal 3-2 ahead of being replaced by Ralf Rangnick. The former has since taken in a spell with Middlesbrough but now finds himself out of work after being sacked by the Championship side earlier this season.

The most recent example of United’s willingness to look to the past came only last season after Erik ten Hag was dismissed. After impressing with Dutch side PSV, former forward Van Nistelrooy returned to Old Trafford to be part of his compatriot’s coaching team.

He was retained after Ten Hag was axed and enjoyed an impressive four-game spell at the helm. Van Nistelrooy led United to a 5-2 Carabao Cup win against Leicester in his first game and followed that up with a 1-1 draw with Chelsea.

The Red Devils saw off PAOK in Van Nistelrooy’s third game before he rounded off an impressive stint with a 3-0 win vs Leicester in the Premier League. Van Nistelrooy was not retained following Amorim’s arrival and was soon handed a new role at the King Power Stadium.
He endured a woeful spell in the Midlands, losing 19 of his 27 games in charge. He has yet to return to the dugout.

headline: Oliver Glasner promises 'final decision' on Crystal Palace future after Man Utd interest
body: Oliver Glasner is to “intensify” talks about a new Crystal Palace deal this month before making a “final decision” about his future. But the Austrian insisted a long contract does not guarantee staying at a club - and claimed new record signing Brennan Johnson could be sold this summer for a “massive fee”.
Glasner, who led the Eagles to FA Cup glory last year, is on Manchester United’s radar as he is out of contract and available for free at the end of the season.

The Europa League champion with Eintracht Frankfurt is a proven winner and a good communicator. He also deploys a variation of the 3-4-3 system used by Ruben Amorim at the South London club, though whether that is a plus point for the Old Trafford club and their fans is now debatable. Palace are also without a win in seven games in all competitions.
Glasner claimed before Christmas that Palace’s hectic fixture schedule - with eight games in December - meant there was no time for contract talks.

But before facing Aston Villa on Wednesday night, the Eagles boss said: “I think in the next weeks, we will intensify the talks. With Macclesfield, Friday again, we go up north, and then everyone gets three days off after Macclesfield and then we have to target four regular weeks and in those weeks we will intensify the talks and I expect to find a final decision.”

Glasner, who replaced Roy Hodgson in February 2024, is the eighth longest-serving manager in the top flight. And he is relaxed about putting pen to paper - and getting linked with the Manchester United job.

During his 51-minute press conference yesterday, the 51-year-old said: “There has been speculation since I arrived. So, believe me, I don't really care about it. I can sign today, or a player can sign a contract extension today and leave in summer. That's why for me, the length of a contract in these times doesn't say anything about your future.

“How long does Brennan's contract last? Four and a half years? So, if you sign a four-year contract, you can't honestly expect that you're always having the same manager, and I think that's why a player never signs just for a manager, he signs for a club, for the vision of a club. It’s not Oliver Glasner.
“Of course, you want to hear from the actual manager but that doesn't mean this lasts forever.

“I talk to Brennan but to be honest, let's talk about just our situation. Brennan signs now, he scores now, 12 goals until summer, a big club comes, pays a massive fee and he leaves. and I sign a new contract and I can't say: 'We talked about it, you know, we've worked together for three years, why don't you stay anymore?'”
Johnson was signed for £35m at the start of the January window after Glasner had previously complained about Palace’s slow buying business.
The South London club have sold Michael Olise and Eberechi Eze in the last two summer windows and are set to lose captain Marc Guehi either this January or at the end of the season.
After winning Palace’s first major trophy and taking them into the UEFA Conference League, it is debatable what more Glasner can achieve at Selhurst Park.
But the Austrian stated: “Believe me, nothing that happens in the transfer window, nothing, affects my decision, nothing. In both directions.”

headline: Amad makes sensational impact as Man Utd in talks with Ole Gunnar Solskjaer
body: Amad has been quick to flaunt his skills as he gears up to play under a new manager at Manchester United. The winger is currently strutting his stuff at the Africa Cup of Nations while United are on the hunt for a new head coach following the dismissal of Ruben Amorim.

The 23-year-old will have certainly caught the eye of potential Old Trafford bosses after a standout performance against Burkina Faso in the last 16. Amad notched a goal and an assist, helping Ivory Coast advance in the tournament.

The United star first demonstrated his finesse with a delicate chip from close range before setting up Yan Diomande with a powerful run. So far in Morocco, Amad has chalked up three goals and one assist in just three starts.

As Darren Fletcher prepares to lead United against Burnley, discussions are already underway about who might be Amad's next coach. United have held preliminary talks with Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, Michael Carrick and Ruud van Nistelrooy about stepping in as caretaker until the season's end.
Amad is no stranger to any of the trio. He made eight appearances under Solskjaer, while Carrick and Van Nistelrooy were part of Erik ten Hag's coaching team at Old Trafford.

Solskjaer appears to be the leading candidate, having expressed a keen desire to return to Old Trafford after being sacked as manager in November 2021. Currently based in Cheshire, the Norwegian's first stint in the hot seat came when he took over as interim boss from Jose Mourinho in November 2018.
His appointment sparked a remarkable turnaround in form and secured him the role permanently on that previous occasion.

Ex-United midfielder Fletcher is currently at the helm and anticipates further discussions after his debut match in charge. "I've had a conversation and the focus was on this game and we'll speak after the game," he revealed during his press conference.
"I've got a game to prepare, training session to organise, speak to players. The focus has been on the Burnley match and we'll speak after the game."
When quizzed about whether he fancied the position long-term, Fletcher responded: "Honestly, it's not something I've thought about.
"That discussion is for after the game. It's all happened so quickly, all my concentration and efforts are going on Burnley."

headline: Man Utd timeline to appoint Ruben Amorim replacement as talks underway with 'several' candidates
body: Manchester United are set to give Darren Fletcher at least two matches as caretaker manager before confirming an interim until the end of the season.
United bid farewell to Ruben Amorim on Monday, marking the conclusion of his 14-month stint at Old Trafford. The 40-year-old's final match in charge was Sunday's 1-1 draw at Leeds.
Ex-United midfielder and current Under-18s coach Fletcher will take the reins for Wednesday's journey to Burnley, with Jonny Evans also returning to the club to lend a hand.
As per The Athletic, United are likely to give Fletcher at least two games - the Premier League fixture against Burnley and Sunday's FA Cup face-off at home to Brighton - in the dugout.
It's further reported that United are then set to announce an interim solution until the close of the 2025/26 campaign before a permanent successor for Amorim is unveiled and confirmed in the summer.

Solskjaer has been seen in the vicinity of his Cheshire home and is reportedly willing to lend a hand to his old club. He held the reins at United for nearly three years before being dismissed in November 2021, securing 91 victories in his 168 matches and leading the Reds to a runner-up spot in his second full season.

After more than three years away from management, the 52-year-old returned to take the helm at Besiktas in January. He guided them to a fourth-place finish in the Turkish Super Lig. However, Solskjaer was let go earlier this season after Besiktas were defeated in the Conference League play-offs.
During a Q&A session at the Oslo Business Forum in September 2024, Solskjaer indicated that he would be ready and willing to answer the call if United ever wanted him back.
Solskjaer stated: "If the family [United] asks, I would say yes every day of the week. It feels wrong to talk about jobs that other people have now, but I would say yes, of course."

headline: Ex-Man Utd boss Erik ten Hag returns to former club four months after brutal sacking
body: Former Manchester United boss Erik ten Hag has been confirmed as technical director of FC Twente after four months without a job. The Dutchman is set to replace current director Jan Streuer next season but will keep a close eye on the club’s operations until then.

Speaking after his appointment was confirmed, Ten Hag said: “I think it's wonderful and special to return to FC Twente, where I've been a supporter at Het Diekman since I was a young boy. My football and coaching careers began here.

“With my experience in youth development, team building, and elite sports culture, I want to strengthen FC Twente's technical foundation together with the Supervisory Board, management, and staff, so the club can sustainably realize its potential as a regional flagship.”

"We are delighted to welcome Erik ten Hag to FC Twente," general manager Dominique Scholten said. "Starting next season, Erik will succeed Jan Streuer, who has made a significant contribution to FC Twente's current status over the past five and a half years. We owe Jan a great deal of gratitude for that."

Explaining why Twente have chosen to appoint Ten Hag, Scholten added: "Erik has an incredible track record in football, and his bond with FC Twente has always remained very strong. At FC Twente, he served as youth coach, head of academy, and assistant coach, and subsequently as head coach and technical manager at renowned clubs, both nationally and internationally.

“We've been in regular contact over the past few months, and our conversations quickly revealed a strong ambition to further develop FC Twente. This ambition aligns with the strategy we recently presented.
“We are raising the bar and further professionalizing the football organization. We took the first step in this direction last year with the arrival of Tim Gilissen."
Ten Hag had been out of work since a doomed spell with German side Bayer Leverkusen. The former United boss was appointed by the Bundesliga club in the summer but was sacked after just three matches.
Ten Hag now returns to Twente, having had three spells with the Dutch side as a player, making 162 appearances. Since then, he has managed Go Ahead Eagles, Utrecht and Ajax in his homeland.

headline: Man Utd star's transfer thrown into doubt by Ruben Amorim sacking - 'Situation is different'
body: Joshua Zirkzee’s move from Manchester United to Roma has been left up in the air, the Italian club’s director Ricky Massara has admitted. The Dutchman was previously linked with a return to Serie A after falling out of favour with Ruben Amorim.

Roma were among the sides interested, with a loan deal touted. But with the Portuguese coach having been sacked this week, that has given Zirkzee fresh hope of career revival at Old Trafford. Speaking about a potential deal, Massara has admitted that a deal now looks slightly more complicated than before as Roma attempt to sign a striker.

“It’s true that there are negotiations in progress with both Atletico Madrid and [Giacomo] Raspadori. The situation is evolving, we knew the timing could be affected by the Spanish Supercup. We expect it to be resolved one way or another fairly soon,” Massara told Sky Sport Italia.

“He [Zirkzee] is a Manchester United centre-forward liked by many clubs, not just us. Naturally, the situation is different after this change of management, there are no contacts in progress, but I wouldn’t focus on individual names.
“We know this window is an opportunity to reinforce the squad in an area where we have struggled to convert chances into goals, so we will try to use it.”
Zirkzee, 24, was signed in July 2024 in a £36.5million move from Bologna. He has gone on to make 63 appearances since then but has scored just nine goals.
The striker has three-and-a-half years left on his contract at Old Trafford. Fresh talk over his future comes amid glowing praise from teammate Matheus Cunha.

Speaking after the recent draw with Leeds United, the Brazilian said: "Josh is a pleasure. I feel like he has a lot of quality. Of course, his situation is not easy, but he has everything to change the situation. We need him. He needs to understand this and then everyone can count on him.
"But yeah, we are here to push him. And I think after the goal last week and the assist today, I think it will give him confidence to be more with us and then understand more his role in the team."

Away from Roma, Zirkzee was also linked with a potential switch to Premier League rivals Everton. The striker could get a couple of chances over the next week should an exit not come to fruition. United take on Burnley on Wednesday, ahead of getting their FA Cup campaign underway against Brighton at the weekend.

headline: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer spotted in Cheshire as Man Utd close in on Ruben Amorim replacement
body: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer is a leading contender to make a comeback at Manchester United on a temporary basis until the season's end. The ex-United boss was sighted in Cheshire amid speculation around him returning to the club.

Solskjaer was shown the door in November 2021 after nearly three years at the helm. The ex-striker took over from Jose Mourinho at the close of 2018 as interim head coach, before being given the job full-time in 2019. United are on the hunt for a stopgap head coach after deciding to give Ruben Amorim the boot on Monday.

While Van Nistelrooy took charge of four United games on an interim basis following Erik ten Hag's dismissal last season, it's also understood that Solskjaer and Carrick have been tapped to take charge until the season wraps up. Solskjaer parted ways with Besiktas in August after the Turkish team were knocked out of the Conference League.

Solskjaer, who played alongside Darren Fletcher, is being considered to steer United until the season's end. The Norwegian is emerging as a front-runner after expressing his eagerness to make a comeback at the club.

During his previous tenure, Solskjaer led the team to consecutive top-three finishes in the Premier League - the first person to do so since Sir Alex Ferguson's era - and guided them to the Europa League final, where they were defeated by Villarreal.

Their second-place finish in 2021 is a feat only he and Mourinho have accomplished since Ferguson's retirement in 2013. In his playing career, the former Cardiff City manager made over 200 appearances for United, clinching six Premier League titles and the legendary treble in 1999.

It's believed that United are seeking an interim solution until the season's end before appointing a permanent head coach for the 2026/27 season. Fletcher is expected to take the reins for Wednesday night's Premier League match against Burnley and Sunday's FA Cup fixture with Brighton.

headline: Man Utd handed double injury boost as Darren Fletcher gives Bruno Fernandes update
body: Bruno Fernandes and Mason Mount will both be available for Manchester United vs Burnley as they aim to kick-start the post-Ruben Amorim era. The Red Devils take on the Clarets at Turf Moor on Wednesday evening in their first game since the Portuguese coach was sacked.

Darren Fletcher has been placed in caretaker charge for the game. And he could have a couple of key players available once again after Fernandes and Mount both missed the draw with Leeds United. United captain Fernandes has missed the last three games, while Mount has sat out of the last two.

Speaking in his pre-match press conference, Fletcher said: “Mason [Mount] and Bruno [Fernandes] were pushing to play against Leeds and the decision was that they weren't quite ready. So they have trained and they should be back in the squad.

“They are on managed minutes and restricted minutes because they have only just returned to training so that is good news, especially because they are players who have been in good form. Mason Mount's form has been fantastic and Bruno Fernandes... you don't have to speak about him.
“He's the captain, the leader of the team. To have them available for selection is obviously great news for me, the players and the club and the fans.”

And while United might have Mount and Fernandes to call upon once more, they are still missing a few stars. Bryan Mbeumo, Amad and Noussair Mazraoui remain at the African Cup of Nations, while Kobbie Mainoo, Harry Maguire and Matthijs de Ligt have recently been struggling with their own issues.

Should the trio remain out, that could see Fletcher add to the squad with youth players - sons Jack and Tyler among those who could be included. The former midfielder stopped short of confirming whether they would be in the squad.

He added: “That would be disclosing team information before the game and I am not going to do that before the game. They were in the training group on Monday because that was already arranged before I got there.

“They have been in the squad recently but obviously we have got a couple of players back from injury so we will assess that tomorrow and we will have to assess a couple of players tomorrow due to the short turnaround from games. They are in the periphery squad but whether they make the match squad I don't know yet, that remains to be seen.”

headline: Jose Mourinho sends message to Ruben Amorim as he makes feelings clear on Man Utd sacking
body: Jose Mourinho has revealed only Ruben Amorim will know the true reason behind his Manchester United exit. The Portuguese coach was sacked earlier this week after a rotten year-and-a-bit in the Old Trafford hot seat.

The Red Devils have already launched the search for his eventual successor but former boss Mourinho has had his say. Now with Benfica, the 62-year-old has told his compatriot to consider why he was sacked.

“What happened with Rúben is something that only Rúben can analyse,” Mourinho said to Portuguese outlet O Jogo. “I believe he will do it, he and his staff. Whether he will do it with you and make his view public, that I do not know.”

Asked if Amorim’s exit could add pressure for other promising young Portuguese coaches, Mourinho added: “I do not understand why it would, but each coach will answer for himself. For me, no, I do not feel it that way.”
Of course, Mourinho is no stranger to the sack. The Portuguese was also fired by the Red Devils following a two-and-a-half year stint at Old Trafford.
While he has refused to compare his experience to Amorim’s, Mourinho has suggested that new opportunities could soon present themselves to the former Sporting Lisbon boss.

“My career at Manchester United, I know it well. I also know the reason why I ended up leaving,” Mourinho said. “But as I always do, or try to do, when I leave a club I close the door and then I do not make comments. I do not analyse externally what happened.
“A door closes and another one will open. That is what happened when I left. The history stayed there, the numbers stayed there, the three medals came home and that is it.”

headline: Man Utd next manager odds amid Ole Gunnar Solskjaer update and Darren Fletcher decision
body: Manchester United are searching for a new head coach following the departure of Ruben Amorim on Monday morning. The club confirmed in a statement: "Ruben Amorim has departed his role as Head Coach of Manchester United.

"Ruben was appointed in November 2024 and led the team to a UEFA Europa League Final in Bilbao in May. With Manchester United sitting sixth in the Premier League, the club's leadership has reluctantly made the decision that it is the right time to make a change.
"This will give the team the best opportunity of the highest possible Premier League finish. The club would like to thank Ruben for his contribution to the club and wishes him well for the future."

Darren Fletcher has been appointed to oversee Wednesday's fixture against Burnley, though it's unclear whether he'll remain in charge for the remainder of the campaign before a permanent appointment is made in the summer. Meanwhile, Michael Carrick and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer have been mentioned as possible interim options for the rest of 2025/26, with reports on Tuesday afternoon suggesting contact had been made between the latter's camp and the club.

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer is currently favourite to take up tenure at United. The Norwegian enjoyed a three-year stint with the club between 2018 and 2021 and has already demonstrated that he can hold his own in the Premier League. An interim or caretaker role until season's end is the most likely scenario, but it remains to be seen as to whether that would interest Solskjaer.

Crystal Palace boss Oliver Glasner has also been linked with being next in line for the United hot seat. The Austrian said of the role in September: "I follow all the rumours - and that's all there is [to it] - neutrally and completely relaxed. Focusing on the daily work with my players and coaches, and trying to enjoy it as much as possible." Out of contract at Selhurst Park this summer, a move to United any sooner looks unlikely considering Glasner's commitment to the club.

Out of the managerial game since stepping down from the England national team last summer, Gareth Southgate has been linked with a role with the Reds for some time now. It is unknown whether he would be willing to step up in an interim job, or whether a permanent role would solely appeal to him at present.

Darren Fletcher has been handed the reins of the first-team for United's clash with Burnley on Wednesday. However, the club could afford him the rest of the season on an interim basis depending on how he fares this week, as they continue to search for a full-time appointment.

An appointment for Thomas Tuchel is highly unlikely at present, considering the German is currently preparing to guide England to glory at the 2026 World Cup. However, his name has been put out there by the bookies.

Enzo Maresca could be set for a return to Premier League management just a week after leaving Chelsea. The Italian head coach has a solid resume with the Blues, including a Europa Conference League title and last summer's Club World Cup win.

Mauricio Pochettino has also found himself highlighted as a suitable candidate to guide United to glory. The Argentine has experience in the Premier League with both Chelsea and Tottenham, although is currently tied up with the USA national team ahead of the World Cup.

Michael Carrick has been out of a job since he was sacked by Middlesbrough last summer, and given his past affiliation with the Reds, could work as a caretaker until season's end. He has previously worked in a caretaker role, and will know what is expected by the board.

Barcelona legend, Xavi, is another name which has been mentioned with regard to taking up a head coach role at Old Trafford. The La Liga legend has enjoyed managerial stints at Al Sadd and at the Camp Nou, but has never managed - nor played for - an English team.

Currently in charge of Ipswich, who are third in the Championship standings, Kieran McKenna is also a bit of a long shot for the job. However, given he has previously worked at the club as an assistant to Jose Mourinho and Solskjaer, he could be a good fit should he have his head turned.

headline: Man Utd transfer news: Deal 'banned' as board risk repeating Werner and Nkunku mistake
body: Manchester United face the significant task of finding a new manager to succeed Ruben Amorim but that hasn't stopped speculation about new signings. This is despite Amorim hinting at a lack of January investment just days before getting the sack.

Darren Fletcher will be in the dugout for Wednesday's Premier League trip to Burnley but the Scot's eventual successor may have targets of their own. Whether those changes come in January or over the summer is a different matter, though, with decisions to be made.
Last year, United were relatively quiet in the winter window. Ayden Heaven joined from Arsenal's academy and was followed to Old Trafford by Patrick Dorgu in a big-money move from Lecce.

There are a number of targets on the club's radar, especially in the midfield area, with the likes of Carlos Baleba and Elliot Anderson potential summer targets. The indication so far is there's unlikely to be the money for marquee signings like that in January but that doesn't mean United will be silent.

While United find themselves waiting until the summer to spend big, there could be scope for more creative deals in the meantime. One of these involves RB Leipzig starlet El Chadaille Bitshiabu, with L'Equipe reporting that the Premier League club could come in with an offer of a loan with an option to buy
They are unlikely to be the only club in the mix, though. Bayer Leverkusen are said to be exploring a similar deal, while Monaco are also keen amid a defensive injury crisis and Lyon also in the mix.

There's one bigger problem, though. Earlier reports from Bild indicated Leipzig are not prepared to sanction an exit for the young defender in January. This, the German outlet claims, applies to both loans and permanent deals.

Bitshiabu returned from a hamstring injury in December but has been used sparingly by his club this season. Just three of his five appearances have come in the league, with Castello Lukeba and Willi Orban ahead of him in the pecking order.

Yan Diomande's fast start at RB Leipzig has prompted plenty of interest from across Europe but a January switch looks to be off the cards. Diomande joined the German club from Leganes over the summer but has already caught the eye, not least with the hat-trick he scored against Eintracht Frankfurt in early December.

Manchester United are one of two Premier League clubs in the mix, according to The Athletic. Tottenham Hotspur are also said to be keen on the Ivorian teenager, who Leipzig expect to command a fee of up to £86million, as are a number of unnamed clubs from elsewhere in Europe.

Premier League clubs have had what can only be described as mixed success when signing players from Leipzig in recent windows. Josko Gvardiol and Dominik Szoboszlai have done the business for Manchester City and Liverpool respectively but attacking players haven't been quite as efficient.

The jury is still out on Benjamin Sesko after he joined United from the Bundesliga side in the last window, while Timo Werner and Christopher Nkunku failed to repeat their Leipzig scoring feats after moving to Chelsea. Both forwards were sold at a loss by the Blues, with Werner returning to Leipzig and Nkunku joining AC Milan.

headline: Liverpool transfer news: £100m battle with Man Utd as Harvey Elliott thoughts emerge
body: Liverpool are yet to dip into the January transfer window but rumours are gathering pace that they could be about to strike. Arne Slot's side were met with an agonising late blow against Fulham on Sunday as they drew 2-2 in the Premier League.

Cody Gakpo looked to have stolen all three points at Craven Cottage only for a late wonder strike from Harrison Reed to rescue a point for Marco Silva's men. The stalemate has some fans agitated that the club need to be active this January.

It's the second consecutive draw for Liverpool after they were also held to a stalemate with Leeds United at Anfield on New Year's Day. The Reds' performance against Daniel Farke's side was slated for lacking creativity.
Rumours are heating up that Liverpool are interested in Brighton's Carlos Baleba. The Cameroon international was reportedly courted by Man United in the summer but a move never materialised.

The Seagulls are rumoured to want in excess of £100million for the ex-Lille youngster, making any move a tricky procedure to pull off. CaughtOffside have reported, however, that the Reds are the latest side to register an interest in acquiring the midfielder's services.
It's said that Brighton are ‘fielding multiple enquiries’ for their star man. However, while a sale in January is unlikely it's expected that Baleba will move on at the end of the season.
Liverpool are also reportedly interested in bolstering their engine room with Crystal Palace's Adam Wharton also linked with the club.

United have also shown a keen interest in Wharton. According to Spanish outlet AS, Slot's side also face a battle with Chelsea, Manchester City and Real Madrid for the player, with the publication claiming that any club will have to fork out a considerable amount for the defensive midfielder.
Liverpool midfielder Harvey Elliott has been linked with a surprise move to Charlotte FC in the States but a new development appears to make a move unlikely.

According to The Athletic, sources close to the player have played down interest in the Englishman securing a move to America. Elliott's season-long loan to Aston Villa hasn't worked out and now attentions have turned to the next step in his career with the World Cup looming.

Elliott has joined Villa on a loan with an obligation to buy - £35m - should he reach 10 appearances for the club. However, Elliott has been stuck on five appearances since October and only two of those were starts.

It's clear Villa won't be meeting the 10 appearances and he cannot be loaned out to another club this season unless their fixtures do not align with the European calendar - hence the Charlotte FC interest.

With Mohamed Salah at AFCON and experiencing poor form, Liverpool could do with a player of Elliott's calibre, so a return to his club could work out well for all parties. However, there is no re-call option in the contract, so the deal would have to be cancelled entirely for him to return to Liverpool.

headline: Arsenal transfer news: Wonderkid target back on radar as Man Utd left behind in £61m race
body: Arsenal’s incredible form does not appear to be slowing them down in the transfer market. With Mikel Arteta’s side six points clear in the Premier League and also top of the Champions League table, they would be forgiven for thinking they already have enough talent in their squad.

They have been boosted by several players such as Gabriel Jesus, Kai Havertz, Ben White and Gabriel Magalhaes returning from injury, adding to the already stacked squad they built in the summer with their stunning spending spree.

Yet, this season has proven there are no certainties when it comes to keeping key players fit, while the Gunners have also been punished in previous January windows for their inactivity come the end of the season.
With Arteta already detailing his plans in relation to bringing in fresh faces this month, there are several names currently being linked with a move to N5.

It is no secret that Arsenal have ramped up their efforts to increase the talent in their academy over the past 18 months. The Gunners’ youth recruitment drive has already seen them snap up Irish midfielder Victor Ozhianvuna, 16, from Shamrock Rovers, as well as Ecuadorian twins Edwin and Holger Quintero, 16, all of whom will officially join next year when they are of age.

It seems they are not willing to stop there, with The Sun reporting Arsenal now want to sign 17-year-old Blackburn Rovers wonderkid Igor Tyjon. The striker made his debut for Blackburn in 2024 as a 16-year-old and is currently on scholarship terms after reportedly turning down the chance to sign a professional contract.

It’s claimed Blackburn have already rejected several bids from Arsenal worth over £1million for the teenager, though they are begrudgingly accepting he will now leave at some stage given his refusal to sign a pro contract. This month is the final chance for Blackburn to command a transfer fee for Tyjon.

Arsenal are reportedly the frontrunners in the race to sign Karim Adeyemi from Borussia Dortmund. The 23-year-old German international has been linked with several Premier League clubs, including Manchester United, having established himself as one of the Bundesliga’s best wingers.

Adeyemi, who is said to be worth around £61m, was last month reported to want to leave the German giants. Now, with the instability caused by Ruben Amorim’s sacking at United, CaughtOffside claims their rivals Arsenal are more likely to sign the player given the proven success of Arteta’s project.

The report states Arsenal’s sporting director Andrea Berta has laid the framework for the deal and "outlined a defined role" for Adeyemi, who is being eyed as long-term competition for Gabriel Martinelli on the left flank.

headline: Marcus Rashford 'loves' manager now favourite for Man Utd job as huge decision made
body: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has emerged as the favourite to take charge of Manchester United from Darren Fletcher until the end of this season after Ruben Amorim's sacking. A return to Old Trafford could come mere months after Marcus Rashford spoke highly of his first stint at the club.

The Norwegian, who has been without a club since his Besiktas sacking last year, is said to be one of the frontrunners alongside Michael Carrick and Ruud van Nistelrooy to take over on a caretaker basis, with the club deciding to wait until the summer to appoint a new permanent boss.

Solskjaer is now the favourite with some bookmakers to be given the nod and knows the club inside out, having spent 11 years of his playing career at Old Trafford before managing the team for three years between 2018 and 2021. He still has a strong bond with a number of United players and recently spoke glowingly about Bruno Fernandes and Harry Maguire.

Rashford, who is currently on loan at Barcelona from United, was also left with a high impression of Solskjaer, having enjoyed some of his best football under the club icon. The forward told the Danish television station TV2 in October last year: "Ole is a fantastic person. I loved playing under him. I can speak for many of the players at Manchester United when I say that we enjoyed playing for him. We played good football under Ole.
"It was a very successful period for me personally. He is a fantastic person, and I don't have a bad word to say about him."
Rashford also said he talks to Solskjaer "from time to time". However, he conceded that "it's been a while now" since they last spoke.
The forward played more and scored more under him than any other United coach. Rashford had 55 goals and 36 assists across 135 matches.

Out of Erik ten Hag, Mourinho and Solskjaer, the academy graduate also managed his best minutes per goal while working with the latter. He averaged a goal every 182 minutes, compared to one every 199 for Ten Hag and every 251 under Mourinho.

Solskjaer took caretaker charge of United after they sacked Mourinho in December 2018, before being appointed as their permanent manager three months later. His tenure lasted just under three years in total, with Michael Carrick and then Ralf Rangnick taking interim charge before Ten Hag eventually took over.
Solskjaer spoke about Rashford during an appearance on The Rest is Football in November. He said: "I've not spoken to Marcus since I left. I text him a little bit, but circumstances.

"I don't know what's happened in his life, but you can see he's certainly enjoying it now in Barcelona. It looked like he didn't enjoy himself here. I don't think that's just Man United [not enjoying it], it's everywhere.

"All the pressures, every single one is different, we don't know what's happened to the players when they walk in in the morning, grumpy, that's the manager's job: 'What's up? I can see something's wrong.'

"We don't know what's happened, we just want him to do well. He's an incredible player when he's in form and happy; he's got that energy. I go back to Erling Haaland, just the energy that he shows all the time, when he's on the pitch, he shows that enthusiasm and energy, that's the least.
"But what is it? Life? Too many games? We don't know, but he's found the right balance."

headline: Man Utd icon Gordon McQueen 'believed heading was behind his dementia'VIDEO
body: Former footballer Gordon McQueen attributed his dementia to heading the ball, the inquest into his death heard on Tuesday.

She told the hearing in Northallerton, North Yorkshire: "He would say 'yes, heading a football all those years probably hasn't helped'. I remember coming home from school and Dad would be in bed. Or having a lie down.
"He would say he's been having headaches. I remember thinking 'why are you having headaches?'" McQueen made almost 350 appearances for St Mirren, Leeds and United between 1970 and 1985.

Hayley told the inquest she did not remember him having head injuries during his career, other than a few concussions. But she outlined how loved ones noticed a change in his personality not long after his 60th birthday. He struggled with his swallowing and that "continued for many years," Hayley said.
"His balance was very, very off and his personality started to change. My dad was very outgoing, dinners, part of the after-dinner circuit. He became off, which wasn't really my dad."
Dysphagia caused the problem with swallowing, though McQueen had also been diagnosed with throat cancer. "He just wouldn't really know what year it was or what day it was," Hayley added.

"He was very active and trying to do crosswords and watch football. He lost the ability to write. He couldn't make a cup of tea. He got confused about what went where. He kept saying, 'there's something not right in my head'. He used to get confused about things. Never people - he had an incredible memory for the past.
"It was more the withdrawn nature of my dad. He would be the centre of attention, but he had to be asked a question to speak."
Michael Rawlinson KC, representing the McQueen family, asked how her father scored his goals.

She replied: "Mainly with his head, from a set-piece." They learned more about his illness after her mum Yvonne spoke with Dawn Astle, daughter of ex-England striker Jeff Astle, who had the brain condition chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) and died in 2002 aged 59.
Prof Willie Stewart, a consultant at Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow who examined McQueen's brain after his death, said that CTE was present.

"Gordon technically fell into the lower stage of the disease, although on the threshold of the higher stage," he added. Prof Stewart said symptoms of CTE were cognitive decline and neuro-behaviour change, and that they "can't be explained by another condition."

He said symptoms were "typical in individuals who have long careers, professional footballers and rugby players". Asked if there was a causal link between CTE and repetitive head injury, he replied: "The answer to that is yes."
Senior coroner John Heath said the post-mortem found pneumonia in McQueen's right lung, mixed vascular dementia and CTE.

Prof Stewart, who conducted a 2021 study on whether certain positions on the pitch were more associated with neurodegenerative disease than others, said: "The players, the goalkeepers who don't head the ball had a risk equivalent to general population, whereas in outfield positions, particularly defenders, the risk was higher."
Mr Heath adjourned the inquest for legal submissions to be made in writing and said he will give his conclusions on January 26

headline: Man Utd are finally listening to Ralf Rangnick's advice after Ruben Amorim sacking
body: Ralf Rangnick looks set to have a major say in Manchester United’s search for a new manager, having green lit a move for Oliver Glasner AND his potential new boss. The Red Devils are on the hunt for Ruben Amorim’s successor following his sacking earlier this week.

Former midfielder Darren Fletcher is taking temporary charge for the trip to Burnley on Wednesday, albeit United will be keen to agree a deal with a more permanent option sooner rather than later. The man tasked with sounding out Amorim’s replacement is set to be Christopher Vivell.

According to Marca, the 39-year-old will be handed a far more prominent role in the club’s hunt for a new boss, as well as player recruitment going forwards. Vivell moved to Old Trafford in the summer of 2024 as an interim director of recruitment, while he was then given the job on a full-term basis in February last year.

Vivell has had spells with Hoffenheim, Red Bull Salzburg and RB Leipzig - crossing paths with Rangnick during his stint with the Austrian and German sides. According to previous reports, Rangnick had head-hunted Vivell for a role at United, only to leave the club shortly after.
Away from Vivell, it also appears that Rangnick would back a move for Crystal Palace boss Glasner. He has been linked with a switch to Old Trafford, with his future at Selhurst Park up in the air.

Glasner’s contract expires at the end of the current campaign. Speaking about his compatriot back in 2023, Rangnick said: "For me, Oliver Glasner is currently one of the most exciting coaches - not only in Germany, but in all of Europe. An absolute top coach.”

Glasner in the meantime has also spoken out about his future and refused to commit to his current employers. He said: "I follow all the rumours - and that's all there is [to it] - neutrally and completely relaxed. Focusing on the daily work with my players and coaches, and trying to enjoy it as much as possible."
Asked about his Palace contract situation last month, Glasner added: "There's no time. Believe me, I'm never thinking about my future right at the moment. It's not important right now.
"I know there are so many rumours. But I don't know how many clubs I managed in the last three months and I'm still sitting here.
"As soon as we will take a decision, number one, the players will hear it, and, number two, [the media] will hear it."

headline: Jurgen Klopp stance on Man Utd job after public Sir Jim Ratcliffe praise
body: Manchester United owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe is a fan of Jurgen Klopp but that's unlikely to be enough to convince the German to make a shock move to Old Trafford. United's sacking of Ruben Amorim has seen attention turn to out of work managers, with former Chelsea boss Enzo Maresca's name coming up, but ex-Liverpool manager Klopp would appear to be a non-starter for a number of reasons.

"Klopp has this ability to drive his players to a frenzy," Ratcliffe said back in March 2024, after his arrival at Manchester United had been confirmed. "Total commitment on the pitch. And, you know, that's one of the things a good coach can do."

At the time, Ratcliffe was asked whether he might be tempted to give Klopp a call in the knowledge the German had decided to leave Anfield at the end of the 2023/24 season. However, he quickly fired back at the reporter who asked the question, telling him: "You can’t ask questions like that".

Ratcliffe hasn't been afraid to bring in staff with connections to rival clubs, most notably bringing in former City Football Group figure Omar Berrada as CEO. However, a move for Klopp would be another matter altogether, and the former Borussia Dortmund boss has already indicated he wouldn't entertain such a switch.

"If you ask me, 'Will you ever work as a manager again?' I would say now no. But I don't know obviously how that will feel because I never had the situation," Klopp said when confirming his Liverpool exit. "What I know definitely – I will never, ever manage a different club in England than Liverpool, 100 per cent.

"That's not possible. My love for this club, my respect for the people is too big. I couldn't. I couldn't for a second think about it. There's no chance. This is part of my life, we are part of the family, we feel home here. There's no chance to do that.

"But all the rest, will I ever work again? Of course, I know myself, I cannot just sit around. I will find something else maybe to do. But I will not manage a club or a country at least for a year, that's not possible, I cannot do that and I don't want to. That's all."

Klopp has stuck to his word, taking a role as Red Bull's global head of soccer but showing no indication of returning to the dugout. Even if he were to make a return, a United move looks to be off the table, with the German previously rubbishing suggestions he had a dream of one day taking charge of the Old Trafford side.

“I really like Eckhard Krautzun but when I think too far in the past I am not 100 per cent sure what is right or wrong but it is still funny. I am sure he thinks it was like this," Klopp said in 2017 after his former Mainz boss Krautzun spoke of that supposed United ambition.

“How could I, as a very average player at Mainz, say to my manager, ‘By the way, if I become a manager I would love to manage Manchester United’. Maybe people think I am a little bit crazy but I am not that crazy. I never thought about something like this.

"[Krautzun] was a big admirer, and is still, of Sir Alex Ferguson. In our first meeting he was wearing a jumper of Manchester United when he came in as a new coach. Maybe he forgot. There are a few funny stories, unfortunately a few things are not exact but still funny. I had fun when I read it but not all of it is exactly like this.”

While Klopp moving to United now looks to be an impossibility given his Liverpool connections, he was approached by the Red Devils back in 2013. At the time, the club was looking for a successor to Sir Alex Ferguson and Klopp was embarking on a run to the Champions League final with Dortmund.

"In the year when Sir Alex retired, they spoke to me," Klopp told Diary of a CEO in 2025. "Of course, they were interested. At that time, I would’ve been interested - I was young, I had a sensational team at Dortmund. They probably thought, ‘What is he doing there?’"
He added: "United tried [to approach me]. It was the wrong time, wrong moment. I had a contract at Dortmund and wouldn’t have left for anybody.
"There were some things in the conversations that I didn’t like. The idea was that big - ‘We get all the players we want’ - and I was sitting there thinking, this is not my project."

headline: Napoli chief makes Scott McTominay stance perfectly clear after Man Utd transfer claim
body: The likelihood of Scott McTominay returning to Manchester United anytime soon appears to have been ruled out by Napoli sporting director Giovanni Manna. Since joining the Serie A side in 2024, the Scotland international has thrived, emerging as one of Europe's most influential midfielders.

McTominay played a pivotal role in Napoli's title-winning campaign last season, scoring 12 goals in 34 games and earning the accolade of Serie A's Most Valuable Player. His rapid rise in Italy has led many to call United's £30million sale one of the club's biggest transfer mistakes in recent memory.

Over the past year and a half, calls for a reunion have grown among fans and reports last month even suggested a surprising comeback could be on the cards for the 29-year-old. Those speculations, however, seem to have been snuffed out by Manna, who emphasised McTominay's value when questioned about Napoli's plans in the January transfer window.

"We're waiting for [Frank] Anguissa, who is an important player, to come back," Manna said. "We've missed him a lot. McTominay is showing that he can be decisive in that role. The coach will make his evaluations."

Since arriving in Naples, McTominay has been a near constant fixture in Antonio Conte's side. While he has not matched last season's goal tally, he has still contributed in critical moments this term, netting important strikes against Inter Milan in Serie A and PSV in the Champions League.

Napoli have no intention of selling their star midfielder, though some reports suggest they could entertain offers around £60m. With United seeking more energy in midfield - and with Casemiro and Kobbie Mainoo possibly leaving this year - McTominay's name has inevitably been mentioned as a target.
Even so, such a move seems improbable. Sir Jim Ratcliffe has emphasised his reluctance to invest heavily in older players and a transfer at that price would contradict the club's shifting strategy.
Questions also remain over United's recruitment priorities following Ruben Amorim's departure, leaving it unclear which positions will be focused on in this window - if any.

There is also no certainty that McTominay would be open to a return. The former United star is clearly flourishing in Italy and his role as Napoli's talisman would be hard to replicate at Old Trafford.

This was, ultimately, part of the reason he left. Despite delivering consistently strong performances for both club and country during his seven years in United's senior squad, McTominay was never treated like a superstar and often played in positions that did not suit his strengths.
Therefore, it increasingly looks as if McTominay's future is set in Naples, where he has found the recognition and freedom that eluded him in Manchester.

For United supporters, seeing a player they once allowed to leave succeed on a bigger stage may sting - but it also underlines that a change of environment can be exactly what a player needs to reach their peak potential.

headline: Man Utd board ignored Sir Alex Ferguson's warning as Ruben Amorim sacked
body: Another Manchester United gaffer has been given the boot and this time it's farewell to Ruben Amorim. The Portuguese boss only managed to hold onto his position for 14 months before being shown the door, with United just three points shy of fourth place in the Premier League.

Yes, United did splash out in the summer, but new signings need time to adjust to fresh surroundings and tactics. There were glimpses of improvement under Amorim this season, even if recent results haven't quite hit the mark.

Alongside recent on-pitch performances, there was allegedly a falling out between Amorim and the board. After the 1-1 draw with Leeds United, the manager sent a pointed message to the board, asserting that he was the manager, not merely the coach.

Since Sir Alex Ferguson's departure in 2013, United have seen a revolving door of managers, with 10 different individuals, including caretakers and interims, taking the reins. David Moyes was the first successor, but his tenure didn't even span a full season, foreshadowing the difficulties future managers would face at Old Trafford.

Louis van Gaal, who arrived with an impressive footballing CV, was brought in to deliver immediate success and wasn't shy about spending money. However, he too was dismissed in 2016, just two years into his stint.

While two years might seem like a long stretch, let's not forget that Sir Alex himself nearly faced the sack in 1990. He went on to become a legend, bagging 13 Premier League titles, five FA Cups, four EFL trophies and two Champions League trophies.
In March 2016, before Van Gaal's departure, Ferguson shared his views on the Dutchman's situation and pointed to injuries as a key factor, backing the manager in the process.

"It is dead easy to be critical," Ferguson said. "You have to be realistic about some things – the number of injuries he has had: Phil Jones has played only seven games this season, Ashley Young, [Antonio] Valencia, [Luke] Shaw, these are big losses.
"It doesn't matter which team you are, if you have players missing of that calibre it has to have an impact on the team.

"The other aspect which is always easy to forget there are also five new players in their first season at United, and two are young players in [Anthony] Martial and Memphis [Depay] and their promise is good.

"You have to have some patience being a Manchester United fan and they have shown that over the years; in Matt Busby's time, in my time. For 150 years of history, it is worth having a couple of years on the quiet side of success because they will always come back and come back strong."

Sir Alex's observations remain just as pertinent now as they were at the time. Since Ferguson's retirement, no United boss has managed to stay in post for more than three years, leading to uncertainty and a sense of constant change at Old Trafford.

Amorim was on a mission to build something at United, implementing his 3-4-3 system that required time for the players to adapt. The team sat sixth in the league table, showing significant improvement from the previous season, and Champions League football was a realistic goal.

The current situation sees United just a few points shy of the top four at the season's halfway mark, after finishing 15th last season. On this basis alone, the decision to sack Amorim seems harsh, regardless of off-pitch events.

Ultimately, United find themselves back at square one. A new manager will have to mould a squad not of their own choosing - Ferguson may well be hoping that the next person to step into his shadow is granted the time and patience needed to finally bring success back to Old Trafford.

headline: MARSHALL: What Sir Alex Ferguson told Darren Fletcher after Manchester United job conversation
body: Darren Fletcher revealed the first phone call he made after being offered the role of Manchester United's interim head coach was to Sir Alex Ferguson, as he sought the blessing of his former boss before taking on the Old Trafford role. Fletcher was offered the position on Monday morning after United sacked Ruben Amorim and his coaching staff. However, he spoke to Ferguson about the job first, seeking the 84-year-old's guidance on whether he should accept it.

Fletcher spent 20 years as an academy graduate and player at Old Trafford, with 18 of those years under the guidance of Ferguson, who remains a regular at United games and at Carrington. He was at the draw with Leeds on Sunday, which proved to be Amorim's final game in charge, and when Fletcher called, he echoed the sentiments his former midfielder had felt about the task at hand and his responsibilities if he were to take it on on a short-term basis.

"I don't like to make any major decisions or things without speaking to Sir Alex and that's something I've done since I've been at the club and since I've left the club and everything I do," Fletcher said. "I've got a really good relationship with Sir Alex so he's probably the first person on the phone actually so I wanted to speak to him first. And ultimately, to get his blessing, to be perfectly honest with you, I think he deserves that respect.

"I wanted to run it by him, what he thought and he was supportive of it and he echoed my thoughts which I've always said. It's your job to do the best for Manchester United when you're an employee of the club. It's amazing when he says something that I try and live and believe every day, so it was comforting for me for him to say that."

Fletcher also reached out to Amorim after the Portuguese head coach's dismissal. He felt he had a good working relationship with the 40-year-old and said he would always be grateful to him for handing a professional debut to his 18-year-old son Jack, while he also named Tyler in his final three matchday squads.
"I've reached out to him, I've not managed to make contact yet but that's understandable," he said. "He's obviously got a lot on his mind and I've been really busy so I've not had the chance to.

"I'd love to because I had a good relationship with Ruben. He was great with me. He was very welcoming to me and to his staff at the end of last season, in terms of being the under-18s coach, in terms of small communication I've had this year, because I've been on another side of the building.

"Always good interactions and ultimately he's the manager who gave my son his debut as well. So as a father I've got a lot to thank him for. Although the boys have gone and earned that themselves, he was the manager who did that. So I've got a good relationship with Ruben, so I'm disappointed for him."

Fletcher has held talks with the players since replacing Amorim, with a particular focus on those who he hasn't worked with before, having been around the first-team before starting his coaching journey with the Under-18s this season.

The Scot held talks with captain Bruno Fernandes to gauge the mood in the squad and then held one-on-ones with summer signing Matheus Cunha and Benjamin Sesko in a bid to get to know them better and find out how they've settled in.

"I have had conversations with players, and it's been time-consuming, so I actually plan to have more conversations," he said. "Maybe my first experience in the first days of Manchester United, you don't have as much time as you think, so in my head I had these plans of speaking to loads of players and it didn't pan out that way.

"I had a conversation with Bruno because that's important because he's the captain and I wanted to speak to him. I focused on a couple of players who I don't know so well, so Matheus Cunha and Benjamin Sesko.

"Senne [Lammens], I actually had a conversation with him not too long ago, but those two I focused on because I've not really got a relationship with them and I wanted to get to know them and I wanted them to get to know me."

headline: MARSHALL: Manchester United hold talks with four former players over interim head coach role
body: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer is a leading candidate to return to Manchester United in a caretaker role until the end of the season, but club officials have also held talks with Michael Carrick and Ruud van Nistelrooy. All three are former players who have had spells in charge of the first team.

Darren Fletcher will add to that number when he leads United out as interim head coach against Burnley at Turf Moor on Wednesday and the 41-year-old Scot has also held talks with the club over the role. United sacked head coach Ruben Amorim on Monday and are set to appoint a caretaker for the remainder of the season, after which they will look to find a permanent successor.
Fletcher said on the eve of the trip to Burnley that he would hold further talks over his future after that game, but United have sounded out Solskjaer, Carrick and Van Nistelrooy over the job.

It is Solskjaer who is emerging as the leading candidate, having made it clear he is desperate to return to Old Trafford, having been sacked as manager in November 2021. The Norwegian came in as interim boss to replace Jose Mourinho in November 2018 and engineered a significant upturn in fortunes, earning him the job on a permanent basis.

His tenure wasn't always smooth, but he guided United to finishes of third and second in two full seasons in charge, before a dramatic slump in his third campaign saw him dismissed after a 4-1 loss at Watford. Solskjaer has more managerial experience than Carrick, Fletcher and Van Nistelrooy and his win record of 54% across 168 games compares well with Amorim's 38%.

Carrick was on Solskjaer's staff during his time in charge and stepped in to replace the club legend after he was sacked. The 44-year-old oversaw two wins and a draw from his three games in charge before leaving when Ralf Rangnick was appointed.
The former midfielder, who made 464 appearances for the club, has since managed Middlesbrough but is available after leaving the Riverside Stadium at the end of last season.

Van Nistelrooy's spell in charge began after he remained in place following the sacking of Erik ten Hag in October 2024. The Dutchman had a record of three wins and a draw from four games and has since had a brief spell at Leicester City before leaving in June 2025.

headline: MARSHALL: What Manchester United have told Darren Fletcher about manager talks
body: Darren Fletcher has been told he will be in charge for Manchester United's Premier League clash with Burnley on Wednesday night before a decision is made on his role later in the week. Fletcher was asked to step up as interim head coach on Monday following the decision to sack Ruben Amorim and his coaching staff and he took his first training session later that day, but talks over extending his role are on hold until the game at Turf Moor.

The Scot confirmed he had added Travis Binnion, Alan Wright and former centre-back Jonny Evans to his coaching staff but revealed he had only been told he would be in charge for one game so far after a conversation with director of football Jason Wilcox.

They have sounded out potential bosses for a caretaker role, including Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and Michael Carrick, but Fletcher's interim role could be extended for the FA Cup tie against Brighton on Sunday at least.

"I’ve had a conversation and the focus was on this game and we’ll speak after the game," he said. "I’ve got a game to prepare, training session to organise, speak to players. The focus has been on the Burnley match and we’ll speak after the game"

Asked if he wanted the job longer-term, Fletcher said: "Honestly, it’s not something I’ve thought about. That discussion is for after the game. It’s all happened so quickly, all my concentration and efforts are going on Burnley."

Fletcher made 342 appearances for United as a player and has represented the club as a first-team coach, academy coach and technical director, before rising to the role of first-team head coach this week.
The 41-year-old admitted the circumstances behind his promotion weren't ideal, but that taking charge of United was something he never dreamed of.
"It’s surreal, it’s an amazing honour to be able to lead a Manchester United team," he said. "I didn't think in my wildest dreams that was something that could happen.

"To lead out a team is an amazing honour and something I’m really proud of. Not in the circumstances I expected, that’s something that doesn’t sit easy with me, but I’ve got a job to do and will think of the honour and pride."

headline: MARSHALL: Man United handed double injury boost vs Burnley
body: Mason Mount and Bruno Fernandes are set to return to the Manchester United squad against Burnley as Darren Fletcher weighs up whether to pick his twin sons, Jack and Tyler, in his first squad. Mount and Fernandes have returned to training at Carrington and will be involved against the Clarets, although neither may be able to complete 90 minutes.

The return of the two midfielders could spell bad news for Fletcher's 18-year-old sons, who both play in midfield and have made the first-team squad recently amid an injury crisis, but Mount and Fernandes were close to featuring against Leeds and are now ready to be welcomed back into the fold.
"I think Mason and Bruno, I think they were pushing to play against Leeds," said Fletcher. "The decision was that they weren't quite ready, so they've trained, so they should be back in the squad.

"But they'll be on restricted minutes because they've obviously just returned to training. So that's good news, especially the fact that obviously players who have been in good form, Mason Mount's form has been fantastic and Bruno Fernandes, you don't have to speak about Bruno, he's the captain, he's the leader of the team, so to have them available for selection is obviously great news for me and for the players and for the club and for the fans."
Tyler is yet to make his United debut, but has been on the bench for the previous three Premier League games, while Jack has come on in three of the last four matches.
Both have trained under their father this week but a decision on whether they make the matchday squad at Turf Moor hasn't yet been taken.
"Well, that would be disclosing team information before the game and I'm not going to do that and give anything away," Fletcher said when asked if he would hand his sons a full debut.

"Look, for me, they were in the training group on Monday because that was already arranged before I got there. They've been in the squad recently, but we've got a couple of players back from injury, so we'll assess that tomorrow.

"We still have to assess a couple of players tomorrow as well because of the short turnaround from games. So they're in the peripheral squad, but whether they make the match squad, I don't know yet. That remains to be seen."

At the start of this season, he was appointed by Bayer Leverkusen before being axed after just two league games. Leverkusen lost at home to Hoffenheim before they squandered a 3-1 lead to 10-man Werder Bremen to draw 3-3.

Now, with United searching for a replacement for Amorim, Ten Hag has returned to football. FC Twente have confirmed his appointment as technical director, with the Dutchman set to begin at the start of February.

A club statement wrote: "Erik ten Hag will join FC Twente on February 1st. He signs a contract until mid-2028. Starting in the 2026/2027 season, Ten Hag will succeed current technical director Jan Streuer, who recently announced his retirement after this season. Ten Hag will already be working in FC Twente's football organization towards the new season.
"Ten Hag returns to the club where he began his professional career. He enjoyed great success as a player at FC Twente and held his first coaching positions there."
On his new job, Ten Hag said: "I think it's wonderful and special to return to FC Twente, where I've been a supporter at Het Diekman since I was a young boy," he said.

"My football and coaching careers began here. With my experience in youth development, team building, and elite sports culture, I want to strengthen FC Twente's technical foundation together with the Supervisory Board, management, and staff, so the club can sustainably realize its potential as a regional flagship."

Ten Hag's new job comes in the same week that United are searching for another head coach. Amorim was dismissed on Monday and the club are currently in talks with Ole Gunnar Solskjaer to return to the club until the end of the season.

Darren Fletcher will oversee United's Premier League clash against Burnley on Wednesday. Talks have also been held with Michael Carrick and Ruud van Nistelrooy regarding their potential return until the end of the season.

headline: MARSHALL: Why Manchester United have added Jonny Evans to their coaching staff
body: Manchester United have added former centre-back Jonny Evans to the new-look coaching staff because of his recent links to the first-team squad and his history with the club. Evans retired as a player after his second spell at Old Trafford came to an end following the 2024/25 season. He went straight into a role as head of loans and pathway but left that position just a month ago.

But Monday's decision to sack Ruben Amorim and almost the entire first-team coaching staff has left United short on bodies. Under-18s head coach Darren Fletcher has taken charge of first-team affairs, with Travis Binnion and Alan Wright also promoted.

Evans has returned in a coaching capacity and will be in the dugout at Turf Moor on Wednesday. The 38-year-old is expected to stay on for the rest of the season as United consider an interim appointment until the end of the campaign.
He made 241 appearances for United across two spells at the club and will know plenty of these players having been part of the dressing room recently, including under Amorim.

"Johnny Evans has come in to help as well, so somebody who's a great association with the club, recently played, knows the players, comfortable in the environment, and a familiar face for the group and the players as well, so those three will assist me for the game tomorrow," said Fletcher.

The 41-year-old Scot is also grateful to have Binnion and Wright alongside him, with the latter only joining the club from Manchester City in recent months. "Travis Binnion, who leads the Under-21s, who I started my coaching career with in the academy, who I've known for five years that I've been here, I actually couldn't ask for anybody better beside me than Travis," Fletcher said. "We've got such a close relationship, worked together for such a long time, somebody I respect, somebody who I've learned a lot from.
"His assistant, Alan Wright, who newly joined the club as well, so the Under-21 staff come and join me."
Fletcher will lead out United at Burnley in what is his first taste of senior management experience, but he is keen to make the occasion about the players rather than himself.
United lacked an attacking identity under Amorim and Fletcher wants to see a side against the Clarets that supporters can be proud of.

"Well, hopefully it looks like a Manchester United team that represents a bit of me," he said. "So I hope it resembles a Manchester United team that fans can be proud of, that I can be proud of. And I'm sure they will because I believe in the players.

"I think we've got good players and I think we've got players who care and I think we've got a lot of quality in that team. And I hope to give them a platform to go out there to express themselves and to show that. And also to challenge them.

"It's about them, it's not about me. It's their season, it's their careers, it's their opportunity. I'm here to help them, but they're the ones who have to cross that white line and go on the pitch and make it happen. So give them some responsibility to go and do that."

headline: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer spotted as Man United icon holds talks over stunning return
body: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer is a strong candidate to make a return to Manchester United on an interim basis until the end of the season after being pictured back in Cheshire today.

Solskjaer was sacked in November 2021 after almost three years in charge. The former striker replaced Jose Mourinho at the end of 2018 as interim head coach, before being appointed to the job permanently in 2019.
Solskjaer left Besiktas in August after the Turkish side crashed out of the Conference League. It's also understood that the Norwegian is now a strong contender to return to Old Trafford.

The 52-year-old was pictured today at a Waitrose store in Wilmslow, Cheshire, near his home in the area. Solskjaer, who was a teammate of Darren Fletcher as a player, is being considered to take control of United until the end of the season.

Solskjaer is emerging as a leading candidate, having made it clear he is desperate to return to the club. During his previous period in charge of the club, Solskjaer recorded successive top league finishes in the Premier League - the club's first since Sir Alex Ferguson - and reached the Europa League final, losing to Villarreal.

He also led them to a second-placed finish in 2021, something only he and Mourinho have achieved since Ferguson retired in 2013. In his playing days, the former Cardiff City boss made more than 200 appearances, winning six Premier League titles and the famous treble in 1999.

It's understood that United are pursuing an interim solution until the end of the season before finding a permanent head coach for the 2026/27 season. Fletcher is set to take charge of Wednesday night's Premier League clash with Burnley and Sunday's FA Cup game with Brighton.
